intro: Sida anomala f. albiflora, commonly known as whiteflower cottonweed, is a herbaceous perennial plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its soft, hairy stems and lobed leaves. The plant produces small, white flowers that are clustered in terminal inflorescences, which are typically visited by various pollinators. Its fibrous roots and hairy foliage help it retain moisture in arid environments. Sida anomala f. albiflora is often found in disturbed soils and along roadsides, showcasing its adaptability to different ecological conditions.
